race.name: Gravel Worlds
race.tagline: 150 miles of relentless Nebraska rollers. $100K purse. Pirate swords for winners. The grassroots championship.
race.race_challenge_tagline: The heat. August in Nebraska is oppressive. Heat adaptation isn't optional—it's

vitals.prize_purse: $100,000 (World Championship jerseys + Sword Trophy for 'Captain of the Gravel Seas')
vitals.aid_stations: Multiple aid stations at key points

climate.description: August brings humidity, heat, and the kind of Midwest summer that tests your heat tolerance

terrain.primary: Classic Nebraska farm gravel with minimum maintenance roads
terrain.surface: Loose gravel, some rough minimum maintenance, occasional sand/mud

gravel_god_rating.score_note: The OG grassroots race since 2010. 'World Championship' title, $100K purse, Pirate ethos. Overall +6 for cultural significance.

length.explanation: The flagship 150-mile course is serious endurance—most riders are out 10-15 hours. Also offers 75mi, 35mi, and the ultra 300-mile 'Long Voyage.' The 150 is the main event and a proper test of diesel power.

technicality.explanation: Gravel roads, not technical terrain. But the surface varies from smooth limestone to deep pea gravel that can wash out wheels. Washboard descents punish bodies. Minimum maintenance roads become mud pits if it rains.

elevation.explanation: Don't let 'Nebraska' fool you—there are ~87 hills on the 150mi course. 10,000ft of climbing in relentless short rollers. One veteran said 'those hills were harder than Unbound' because there's never any recovery.

climate.explanation: August in Nebraska is brutal. Heat indices regularly exceed 100°F. 2024 saw one-third of the 150mi field DNF due to heat. Humidity makes it worse. Afternoon thunderstorms can turn MMR sections to mud.

altitude.explanation: Low elevation Nebraska farmland. No altitude concerns. The challenge is heat and terrain, not thin air.

logistics.explanation: Lincoln is a real city with airports, hotels, and amenities. Much easier logistics than rural Kansas or Utah. Good restaurant options, university town vibe.

adventure.explanation: Rolling farmland isn't dramatic mountain scenery. The 'adventure' is internal—the mental battle of relentless hills and heat. The pirate theme adds character, but the landscape is endless corn and gravel.

prestige.explanation: 16-year history from grassroots to $100K prize purse. The 'World Championship' branding is bold but earned through longevity. Pirate sword trophies are iconic. Part of gravel's original DNA.

race_quality.explanation: Well-organized with checkpoint support, convenience store stops mapped, and proper timing. The 'gravel family' ethos means inclusive vibes. They celebrate last-place finishers with 40 bottles of champagne.

experience.explanation: The pirate theme, the relentless rollers, the August heat survival—it creates memories. The 'DFL' celebration is unique. Finishing 150 miles of Nebraska hills in August heat is genuinely hard.

community.explanation: Peak grassroots gravel culture. 'Be Cool' is Rule #1. The pirate aesthetic, the inclusive spirit, the celebration of all finishers. This is what gravel community looks like.

field_depth.explanation: The $100K purse (2025) draws serious pros. The 300-mile Long Voyage attracts ultra specialists. Age-group competition is strong with Midwest cycling clubs well-represented.

value.explanation: $195 for the 150mi is pricey but includes checkpoint support, finisher awards (pirate sword!), and a proper multi-day festival. The $100K purse justifies premium pricing.

expenses.explanation: Lincoln is affordable. Hotels are reasonable. Flights to LNK or OMA are manageable. Midwest pricing keeps costs down compared to coastal events.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Worlds represents what the sport was before corporate money arrived. It's authentic, community-driven, and legitimately hard. The 'World Championship' name started as a joke but the race earned its reputation through genuine challenge.
strengths: Authenticity: Grassroots soul in a corporatized sport.
The community: Pirate culture means inclusive, welcoming energy.
The challenge: 150 miles in August Nebraska heat is no joke.
weaknesses: The heat: August humidity and heat can be punishing.
Nebraska: Not a tourist destination. You're here for the race.
Infrastructure: Less polished than Life Time events.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want to experience what gravel racing meant before it went mainstream, Gravel Worlds is your pilgrimage. Harder than it looks, more meaningful than its name suggests.

black_pill.title: THE THING NOBODY TELLS YOU
black_pill.reality: The 'World Championship' is self-proclaimed and tongue-in-cheek—but the race is legitimately hard. Don't let the name fool you into thinking it's a marketing gimmick. The course will humble you.
consequences: August heat training is mandatory. If you can't handle 90°F+ humidity, don't start.
150 miles is ultra-endurance. This isn't a 'long ride'—it's a day-long test.
Lincoln, Nebraska isn't a destination. You're coming for the race.
black_pill.expectation_reset: This is a grassroots ultra-endurance race in brutal conditions. The prestige is earned through suffering, not production value.

final_verdict.one_liner: The OG grassroots gravel race—where the spirit of the sport lives on in Nebraska summer heat.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you value authenticity, community, and genuine challenge over polish. Yes if you can handle August Midwest heat. Not if you need corporate production value.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want heat without the distance: Unbound 100. If you want distance without the heat: fall ultra events. If you want grassroots elsewhere: local favorites.

logistics.airport: Omaha (OMA) - 1 hour. Lincoln (LNK) - 15 minutes but limited flights.
logistics.lodging_strategy: Lincoln has ample hotels. Book 1-2 months ahead.
logistics.food: Lincoln has solid food options. Not a foodie destination but functional.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday at event venue. Grassroots vibe, efficient process.
logistics.parking: Start area parking is generally available.

history.founder: Corey Godfrey / Gravel Cycling Hall of Fame
history.origin_story: 'Exploring together since 2010.' Started as a tongue-in-cheek 'World Championship' for a sport that didn't have one. 15+ years later, it's a legitimate bucket-list event with $100K prize purse. Winners earn 'Captain of the Gravel Seas' title and a Sword Trophy. Now includes running series (16mi) and gravel triathlon.
notable_moments: One of the original grassroots gravel races
Created the 'Pirate' ethos in gravel culture
Gravel Cycling Hall of Fame is based here
history.reputation: The OG grassroots race. Where the gravel movement's spirit lives on.

course_description.character: Long, hot, and humbling. NOT flat—'hill after hill after hill' averaging 4-5% grade either up or down the entire 150 miles through iconic cornfields. 10K+ feet of climbing with no single killer climb, just relentless rolling. Mud possible in wet years.

suffering_zones.label: Heat Onset
suffering_zones.desc: Morning cool is gone. The Nebraska sun starts earning its reputation.

suffering_zones.label: Century Club
suffering_zones.desc: You've done 100 miles. There's 50 more. In August heat.

suffering_zones.label: Mind Games
suffering_zones.desc: Close enough to finish to hurt. Far enough to break.

course_description.signature_challenge: The heat. August in Nebraska is oppressive. Heat adaptation isn't optional—it's survival.
